summary: Alpha 66 was an anti-Castro Cuban exile group active from the early 1960s through the 1970s. The group engaged in propaganda efforts and claimed actions within Cuba. Antonio Carlos Veciana Blanch founded Alpha 66. The documents reveal concerns and reactions to Alpha 66's activities from both the U.S. State Department and the Cuban exile community. One document mentions a tip about the yacht Potomac possibly being used by Alpha 66 to transport weapons. The group's activities in Los Angeles during September 1970 are also documented. Robert G. Halley, former Chief of Station for CIA's JMWAVE in Miami, discussed Cuban operations and relationships with exile groups, including Alpha 66, around the time of the Kennedy assassination.
significance: Alpha 66 is mentioned in the context of Cuban operations and relationships with exile groups around the time of the Kennedy assassination, as discussed in a Senate Select Committee hearing. One of the founders, Antonio Veciana, has been alleged to have connections to Lee Harvey Oswald.
